routing_summary.excerpt_summary: Section 25 of the -bis draft specifies IANA actions: updating references from RFC 8415 to this document, adding a new "Status" column to DHCPv6 registries, and marking certain option codes and a status code as Obsolete. The referenced RFC 8415 IANA section shows prior registry modifications and context for these updates.

Temporal.explanation: No sequencing, timers, or ordering of events in the IANA instructions.

ActorDirectionality.explanation: Only IANA actions are described; no protocol roles or message directions involved.

Scope.explanation: Scope (which registries and specific rows) is clearly enumerated; no apparent over-breadth or omission visible from this text.

Causal.explanation: The registry changes (marking items Obsolete, adding a Status column, updating references) are straightforward and do not obviously break protocol behavior or interoperability.

Quantitative.explanation: Only registry identifiers and port numbers are involved; ranges and numeric values align with existing usage.

Deontic.explanation: This is “IANA is requested to…” guidance, not conflicting protocol-level MUST/SHOULD requirements.

Structural.explanation: No ABNF/YANG/diagrams here; the tabular registry references are consistent with prior RFC 8415 text.

CrossRFC.explanation: Cross-references (dhcpv6-parameters, auth-namespaces, multicast addresses, port numbers) line up with how RFC 8415 already used them; updating references from 8415 to this document is coherent.

Terminology.explanation: Terms like “Obsolete”, option names, and status codes match earlier sections and the existing registries.

Boundary.explanation: No edge-case behaviors or special-case algorithmic rules; this is pure registry administration.

candidate_issues.short_label: No apparent inconsistencies or underspecification in IANA actions for DHCPv6 registries
candidate_issues.sketch_for_experts: From the combined view of Section 25 in the -bis draft and the IANA guidance in RFC 8415, the requested actions (adding a Status column, marking IA_TA and UNICAST options and UseMulticast status code as Obsolete, and updating references from RFC 8415 to the new RFC across the listed registries) are consistent with the protocol changes elsewhere in the draft (obsoleting IA_TA, Server Unicast, and UseMulticast, and already-obsoleted delayed authentication). There is no visible mismatch between what the protocol text says is obsolete and what the registries are instructed to mark Obsolete, nor any conflicting registry semantics.
